p: Ways must therefore be found to construct useful scientific information on the regional scale, and even on the local scale, that reflect an appropriate level of uncertainty yet retain the relevant information about climate risk. It has recently been argued [ 11] that storylines—physically self-consistent unfoldings of past events, or of plausible future events or pathways—provide a potential way forward, both for the interpretation of the observed record and for the description of plausible futures. However, storylines are inherently subjective and thus would seem to be at odds with more probabilistic approaches, which give the appearance of objectivity. The purpose of this paper is to place storylines within a broader epistemological framework.
